SHO? FIRING IN MINES.
An important case came on at the Gateshead Gonnty
Police-court on Saturday, proceedings having been
taken by the Home Office against the manager of the
Uaworth Colliery, for iegal shot-firing on March 2nd,
the day on which the disastrous explosion, by which
forty-two lives were lost, ocvurred at that calliery.
The summons was issued against Mr. A, 8. Palmer,
who was present, asagent of the colliery. Mr, Arnold
Morley, M.P., proseeuted on behalf the Crown, and
Mr. R. PF. Cooper, Neweastle, appeared for the owners,
Mr. Morloy said the prosecution was taken under 35
and 36 Vic., chap. 76, of the Mines Regulation Act.
With regard. to the use of gunpowder, it was provided
that it should only be nsed in cartridges, and not
within three months after any iuflammable gas had
been found in the mine, The prosecution relied in this
case on the fact that inflammable gas had been found
in the mine within three months of the firing of the
shot, and the question was whether the regulation
had been complied with, it being requisite under the
Act for some competent person duly appointed for
that prrpose to examine the place where the shot was
to be fired immediately before the firing, and not to
allow it to be discharged except it was safe to do so,
Tt was also provided that persons ordinarily employed
in the mine were to be out of it or that part of it
whore the explosive was to be used, Me, Caoper aaid
he did not dispute that gas had been found, but it
was not fonnd within the conditions of the Act, He
was prepared to prove that it was due to a temporary
stoppage in the ordinary ventilation appliauces, and
was removed when the ventilation was pub righs.
After evidence had been given on both sides, it was
ayread between Mr, Morley and Mr. Cooper that th
question at issue was really a legal one as to the mean-
ing of the Act with regard to the eonditions under
which shot-firing should not take place, The Court
waa, therefore, asked not to give its decision, bunt to
